Hello
We did the 70,000 franchise fee as payment for the franchise. While we where looking for a site his Growing minds became for sale and the owner of the franchise said it would be good to take Growing minds and change it to Uptown Montessori under the franchise name. I believed him and he did all the disclosure and discover on his end. The Supervisor was running the day to day operations and was told I needed to keep her and the staff they had. A week after we toke over we she demanded a big raise from 60k a year 5 days a week to almost 70k a year only working 4 days a week. She was holding all the information that ran the business and I was informed to take her deal and then find a way to get her out rhe door in a few months. Right now I do not feel welcome their and I do not want to even show up. I know on paper it's my business but to me it feels like it's hers not mine
Marjan

candidates.body:

I don’t have a preference with regards to mediation/arbitration. My
preference is what is best for me. I always imagined that this document
would be air tight and not require?



I don’t think it will be in my interest to negotiate. I would be interested
in it, as long as it could only be triggered by me.

be something where she’s automatically terminated at separation. Can this
be handled in the prenuptial agreement?

________________________________
From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
Sent: February 5, 2026 11:09 AM
To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>
Subject: Re: Corporate Law Firm

Hi Marjan

Good day. I have the FDD, thank you.

At a preliminary level, I have questions about how the transaction was structured, particularly in relation to the franchise agreement that was entered into and the fee that was paid. To start with, can you confirm whether a $70,000 initial franchise fee was paid, and whether you were given an explanation at the time for why the transaction was treated as a new franchise rather than a transfer or change of control?

Before I can assess whether there is a legal issue to be examined, it would be helpful to make sure I understand the situation from your perspective. In particular:

  *   What concern or issue prompted you to reach out now?

  *   Who was responsible for day-to-day management of the business at the time of the transaction, and how was that role described to you?

  *   Were you told that any individual’s continued involvement was expected or required when the deal was completed?

The reason I ask is that issues involving disclosure and transaction structure are treated differently from operational or personnel disputes, and I want to be clear on the factual background.

Once I have that context, we can discuss whether there is a legal issue worth pursuing and what the appropriate next steps might be.

Best regards



Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor

candidates.subject: Re: Corporate Law Firm
candidates.body:
Hello
We did the 70,000 franchise fee as payment for the franchise. While we where looking for a site his Growing minds became for sale and the owner of the franchise said it would be good to take Growing minds and change it to Uptown Montessori under the franchise name. I believed him and he did all the disclosure and discover on his end. The Supervisor was running the day to day operations and was told I needed to keep her and the staff they had. A week after we toke over we she demanded a big raise from 60k a year 5 days a week to almost 70k a year only working 4 days a week. She was holding all the information that ran the business and I was informed to take her deal and then find a way to get her out rhe door in a few months. Right now I do not feel welcome their and I do not want to even show up. I know on paper it's my business but to me it feels like it's hers not mine
Marjan



Sent from Outlook<http://aka.ms/weboutlook>

________________________________
From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
Sent: February 5, 2026 11:09 AM
To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>
Subject: Re: Corporate Law Firm

Hi Marjan

Good day. I have the FDD, thank you.

At a preliminary level, I have questions about how the transaction was structured, particularly in relation to the franchise agreement that was entered into and the fee that was paid. To start with, can you confirm whether a $70,000 initial franchise fee was paid, and whether you were given an explanation at the time for why the transaction was treated as a new franchise rather than a transfer or change of control?

Before I can assess whether there is a legal issue to be examined, it would be helpful to make sure I understand the situation from your perspective. In particular:

  *   What concern or issue prompted you to reach out now?

  *   Who was responsible for day-to-day management of the business at the time of the transaction, and how was that role described to you?

  *   Were you told that any individual’s continued involvement was expected or required when the deal was completed?

The reason I ask is that issues involving disclosure and transaction structure are treated differently from operational or personnel disputes, and I want to be clear on the factual background.

Once I have that context, we can discuss whether there is a legal issue worth pursuing and what the appropriate next steps might be.

Best regards



Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor

> Hi Harry

> best regards
>
> A. Changes that specify and tighten Diameter’s obligations
>
> 1. Support responsiveness and escalation (s. 1). Diameter now:
>

>    -
>

>

> Diameter must:
>
>    -
>
>    notify within 24 hours of identifying an Error,
>    -
>
>    use commercially reasonable efforts to identify root cause and
>    implement corrective action,
>    -
>
>    provide periodic status updates for material Errors,
>    -
>
>    deliver a written post-incident summary after resolution.
>
> 3. Transaction restriction transparency (s. 3.8).  where Diameter or the
> bank restricts, blocks, reverses, or delays Transactions, Diameter must
> provide prompt written notice including:
>
>    -
>
>    a high-level reason category (AML, sanctions, liquidity, etc.),
>    -
>
>    whether the action is final or remediable,
>    -
>
>    what information or steps are required for further review (where
>    permitted).
>
> 4. Change-management consultation. (s. 4).  For material program changes
> (outside emergencies/regulatory direction):
>
>    -
>
>    30 days’ prior notice is required, and
>    -
>
>    Diameter must consult with SnowCap where changes materially restrict
>    transaction types, volumes, or flows.
>
> 5. Suspension communications & remediation (s 5).  During a Suspension
> Event, Diameter must:
>
>    -
>
>    designate an escalation contact, and
>    -
>
>    provide periodic updates (where reasonably practicable).
>
> B. Changes that loosen Stream / SnowCap’s obligations
>
> Changes aim to reduce over-breadth, soften strict liability, or introduce
> reasonableness and cure concepts for SnowCap.
>
>    1.
>
>    Recordkeeping failures no longer automatically “material breach” (s.
>    14.2). Failures relating to Records, End User Information, or
>    authorizations are not material breaches unless:
>
>
>    -
>
>    there is a pattern of failure,
>    -
>
>    a material Error results and is not timely corrected, or
>    -
>
>    there is a material violation of law or Network Rules.
>
>
>    2.
>
>    Good-faith dispute protection on fees (s 8).  Diameter may not suspend
>    or terminate based on fees disputed in good faith, provided SnowCap:

>
>    -
>
>    gives notice within 10 Business Days, and
>    -
>
>    works in good f

candidates.subject: Follow Up and Next Steps
candidates.body:
Hi Matthew,

Just following up briefly on my note from Monday. Thank you again for your message, I really appreciate the transparency.
I completely understand, and I’m very glad to hear that you’d like to find a way for us to work together.

I also wanted to emphasize that I would be very happy to get started right away with whatever hours you have available initially. My main priority is the opportunity to begin working with you, learn the practice, and contribute as things ramp up.

Your suggestion to touch base again in a couple of weeks makes perfect sense, and once the joint venture is finalized and workflow becomes clearer, we can certainly revisit what a more consistent weekly structure might look like at that time.

I also wanted to mention that I’m currently in touch with a few individuals and business contacts who may be seeking legal support in the near term, and I would be very happy to explore opportunities to bring additional work into the firm as we get started.

Whenever you have a moment, I’d be happy to connect briefly by phone, but I’m also very comfortable moving forward by email if easier.

Thank you again. I’m very excited about the possibility of working together.

Warm regards,

Laura Hinton

Hi Matthew-
As mentioned, I sent lease to lender (TD) for final review before sharing with LL. Seems they want us to go much further on the two clauses marked as problematic as related to CSBFP program. I asked for exact clarity on what needs to come out and have pasted response below. I feel weird striking it myself without running through you. Can you please have a look, let me know if it makes sense (no choice, it seems), then strike as part of final redline. 
I will then do my best to summarize all changes and share with LL. Fingers crossed, ugh. Stressful!
Thank you. Note from bank here:

Good morning Chris,

I hope you are well. 

Thank you for your continued support throughout this process.

Regarding the lease, I wanted to discuss two specific clauses that present challenges for our agreement:

- Section 3.4 – Leasehold Improvements: The clause states, "All Leasehold Improvements shall immediately upon installation become the absolute property of the Landlord, free and clear of any liens or encumbrances." The following needs to be removed: the entire section 3.4 (a, b, c, d). We need to reference the property address in the General Security Agreement, and this clause prevents us from doing so.

- Section 8.2 – No Financing by Tenant of Leasehold Improvements: The clause states, "The Tenant shall not create any lien, mortgage, charge, conditional sale agreement or other encumbrance in respect of its Leasehold Improvements." Removing this clause would allow us to secure the leaseholds, which is necessary for our agreement.

You are requesting financing on the leasehold improvements, but these clauses prevent you from doing so. 

Thank you for your attention to these matters. If you have any questions or need further clarification, please let me know. I look forward to working together on this.

Kind Regards,
 
Tisanth Thanabalasingam
Remote Account Manager, Small Business (Remote Strategy) | TD  Business Banking

candidates.subject: Re: hi
candidates.body:
Ok I can talk this week.
Just took a 2 second look.  Looks like a potentially great opportunity if
they send you clients.
Yes need to name the relationship -  the term “partner” is wrong word.
Unless it is actually meant to be a partnership?
Services definition is very vague.  Not sure if the services are legal
services or not?  That needs to be clear and if not, how to ensure no
reliance on legal advice.
The SOW is not attached - No Appendix 1.

I’ve not got experience entering into anything like this so I would seek
legal advice from a senior partner somewhere with actual experience.
Compliance risks could include obvious partnership liability risks but also
advertising and payment compliance.

I never like a deal that agrees to get paid when they get paid and also
gives them full rights to write down your bill or offer discounts or
whatever deal to the client, and no duty to collect promptly.  Need to
flesh out that piece.

More when we chat.
